name: Tokyo
intro_vibe: The Electric Capital: Where ancient tradition meets neon-lit future.

general_info.description: Tokyo is the capital of Japan and the world's most populous metropolitan area. A city of contrasts, Tokyo seamlessly blends ancient temples with skyscrapers, traditional tea ceremonies with cutting-edge technology, and serene gardens with the chaotic energy of Shibuya Crossing.

etiquette_tips: Bow for Greetings: A slight bow (15°) is standard. Deep bows (45°) are for apologies or gratitude.
No Tipping: Tipping is considered rude. Service is included in the price.
Shoes Off Indoors: Remove shoes when entering homes, ryokan, temples, and some restaurants.
Quiet on Trains: No phone calls on trains. Keep your voice low and respectful.
Chopstick Etiquette: Never stick chopsticks upright in rice (funeral practice) or pass food chopstick-to-chopstick.

essential_phrases.local: ありがとうございます (Arigatou gozaimasu)
お会計お願いします (Okaikei onegaishimasu)

neighborhoods.name: Shibuya
neighborhoods.description: The beating heart of Tokyo's youth culture. Famous for the busiest crossing in the world, trendy fashion, and neon lights.

neighborhoods.name: Shinjuku
neighborhoods.description: Tokyo's busiest district with skyscrapers, entertainment, and the serene Shinjuku Gyoen garden as an oasis.

neighborhoods.name: Asakusa
neighborhoods.description: Old Tokyo preserved. Historic temples, traditional shops, and the nostalgic atmosphere of Edo-era Japan.

neighborhoods.name: Harajuku
neighborhoods.description: The epicenter of kawaii culture, street fashion, and youth trends. Takeshita Street is the heart of organized chaos.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: Tokyo's train system is legendary. Clean, punctual, and covers everywhere.
details: JR Yamanote Line: Circular line connecting major stations (Shibuya, Shinjuku, Tokyo Station).
Tokyo Metro: 13 lines covering the city. Get a Suica or Pasmo card.
Shinkansen: Bullet trains for day trips (Kyoto in 2.5 hours).
Google Maps: Essential for navigating the complex train system.

logistics.title: Scams to Avoid
logistics.summary: Tokyo is extremely safe, but a few tourist traps exist.
details: Kabukicho Touts: Avoid aggressive club promoters in Shinjuku's red-light district.
Overpriced Bars: Some hostess bars charge ¥100,000+ for a drink. Check prices before entering.
Fake Monks: Don't accept 'blessings' from monks who demand payment.

logistics.title: Safety Basics
logistics.summary: Tokyo is one of the safest cities in the world.
details: Lost Items: You'll likely get your wallet/phone back. Check station lost & found.
Earthquakes: Small quakes are common. Stay calm and follow locals.
Women: Solo female travel is very safe, even at night.

logistics.title: Apps to Download
logistics.summary: These apps will make Tokyo navigation seamless.
details: Google Maps: Includes train routes, times, and platform numbers.
Suica App: Digital train card (iPhone only).
Google Translate: Camera function for reading menus/signs.
Tabelog: Japanese Yelp for finding top-rated restaurants.

must_eat.description: Fresh fish over vinegared rice. Try conveyor belt sushi (kaiten-zushi) for budget-friendly options or splurge at Tsukiji Market.
Rich broth, springy noodles, and toppings. Tokyo-style is shoyu (soy sauce) based. Ichiran is famous for solo booths.
Lightly battered and fried seafood or vegetables. Best enjoyed at specialized tempura restaurants with dipping sauce.
Japanese pub with small plates (yakitori, edamame, karaage) and drinks. Casual, loud, and fun.
7-Eleven, Lawson, FamilyMart. Fresh onigiri, bento boxes, and hot oden. Better than most restaurants.

items.name_local: 渋谷スクランブル交差点
items.description: The world's busiest pedestrian crossing. Up to 3,000 people cross at once during peak times. View from Starbucks above.
Inspired by the Eiffel Tower, this red and white landmark offers city views. Best seen illuminated at night.
The tallest structure in Japan at 634 meters. Observation deck offers 360° views on clear days.
Tokyo's oldest temple (628 AD) in Asakusa. Walk through the iconic Kaminarimon Gate and Nakamise shopping street.
Serene Shinto shrine surrounded by forest, dedicated to Emperor Meiji. Traditional weddings are often held here.

items.name_local: チームラボボーダレス
items.description: Digital art museum with immersive, interactive installations. Rooms flow into each other with no boundaries. Book ahead.
Otaku paradise. Multi-story electronics stores, anime shops, maid cafes, and retro arcades.
Narrow pedestrian street packed with trendy fashion, crepe stands, and kawaii culture. Weekends are chaotic.
Tokyo's upscale shopping area with luxury brands, department stores, and high-end restaurants.
